document.docAuthor: Ferreira, Luciane Augusto De Azevedo & Tavares, Marcos
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of Pachycheles (Crustacea: Anomura: Porcellanidae), with taxonomic remarks on two other porcelain crabs from the remote oceanic archipelago of Trindade and Martin Vaz, South Atlantic Ocean

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of Pachycheles (Crustacea: Anomura: Porcellanidae), with taxonomic remarks on two other porcelain crabs from the remote oceanic archipelago of Trindade and Martin Vaz, South Atlantic Ocean

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Porcellana amoena Guérin-Méneville 1855
, pl. 2, fig. 2. [type locality Cuba].
Petrolisthes serratus
Henderson 1888 : 107
, pl. 11, fig. 2. [type locality off Bahia, Brazil].
Petrolisthes galathinus
.—
Moreira 1920 : 132
[not
Petrolisthes galathinus (Bosc, 1802)
].
Petrolisthes amoenus .
—
Schmitt 1935 : 185
.

Size . Largest male, cl 9.5, cw 9.2 ( MZUSP 34744). Largest female, cl 8.6, cw 8.3 ( MZUSP 34789). Smallest ovigerous female, cl 5.5, cw 5.2 ( MZUSP 34758).

Coloration . In
Petrolisthes amoenus
( Fig. 5 A) color patterns vary strongly with size. Small specimens (cl 3.9, cw 3.5) presents brownish to orange dots over a dominant white background; small dots cluster together forming larger dots or slender stripes on the carapace and chelipeds. On P2–5 there is a reticulate pattern of brownish to orange thick stripes. In larger specimens (cl 5.7, cw 5.3) the carapace is regularly and densely covered by a reticulate pattern of slender, carmine red stripes over a much more discrete white background. The cheliped carpus, merus and proximal half of propodus have carmine red stripes variable in size and thickness over a dominant white background, while the distal half of the propodus, fixed finger and dactylus are carmine red. On P2–5 the reticulate pattern of thick stripes is carmine red in color ( Fig. 5 B). Full grown specimens (cl 9.4, cw 8.5) are mostly reddish to dark orangish on carapace and chelipeds; the reticulate pattern on P2–5 is carmine red crossed by 3 or 4 transversal white stripes intercalated with the remaining red. A large carmine red spot over a light orangish background is well characteristic on the Mxp 3 merus ( Fig. 5 C). The ventral surface of the body is also distinctly reddish with small light yellowish areas ( Fig. 5 C).

Habitat .
Petrolisthes amoenus
has been reported to live on corals, calcareous algae, sponges and under rocks, from shallow waters down to depths of 140 m ( Veloso & Melo 1993 ; Poupin & Lemaitre 2014 ; Ferreira & Melo 2016 ). In Trindade and Martin Vaz Islands
P. amoenus
was frequently found along with
P. meloi
sp. nov.
in association with calcareous algae; 8–30 m depth.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5 . (A–D)
Petrolisthes amoenus (Guérin-Méneville, 1855)
. (E–F)
Petrolisthes marginatus Stimpson, 1859
. (A) Female, cl 3.9, cw 3.5, dorsal view (MZUSP 34703). (B) Ovigerous female, 5.7 cl, 5.3 cw, dorsal view (MZUSP 34688). (C–D) Male, cl 9.4, cw 8.5, dorsal and ventral views, respectively (MZUSP 34753). Note in A–C color pattern varying strikingly with size. (E-F) Female, cl 8.4, cw 8.6, dorsal and ventral views, respectively (MZUSP 34648). Scale bars = 5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks . Some degree of morphological variation is observable in
Petrolisthes amoenus
, some of which related to the size of the specimens: (1) presence of dense, short, robust setae on the dorsal surface of the carapace mainly in small specimens (such setae are usually absent in larger specimens and absent in full grown specimens); and (2) the degree of development of the outer orbital angle, which can be furnished with a spine variable in size (or even show as only a slight bump) in large specimens (outer orbital angle provided with a conspicuous spine in small specimens). However, some morphological variations are observable in specimens of same size and sex: (1) antennular basal segment with 4 to 6 distal spines (usually 4); (2) 4 or 5 spines on the mesial margin of P1 carpus; and (3) a fringe of setae on the lateral margin of the P1 propodus either slightly evident and present only on its proximal half or quite evident along the entire lateral margin of the P1 propodus.

Moreira (1920) recorded
Petrolisthes galathinus (Bosc, 1802)
from Trindade Island based on two specimens (cl 7 mm , cw 6 mm and 11 mm , cw 10 mm , respectively) no longer available in the collections of the Museu Nacional, Rio de Janeiro . However, no specimens of
P. galathinus
were recovered from Trindade since them. It is not uncommon to find specimens of
P. amoenus
misidentified with
P. galathinus
in museum's collections and it may well be that the specimens from Trindade assigned by Moreira to
P. galathinus
actually belong to
P. amoenus
.
